div.p: Let me offer my best felicitation to you, dear Mr Wilson, at the new year's commencement; may it be to you and your florishing family one of much happiness, and be followed by a long series of equally joyful years.

As you have taken such a generous interest in my fate, I must mention, that my general health has improved in the pure sea-air here; but my cough is as yet but little subdued; it is rather too windy and often too cold for me here. I contemplate however to stay til the middle of the month, as it will take me til then, to finish the msc. for the 10th Decade of the Eucalyptography,
B84.11.02. as my time is besides daily taken up with much official correspondence. It will however be wise for me, to stay away from the Melbourne Summer-air for a few weeks longer, and I shall after my return ask Mr Berry, to allow me to go to some dense forest -country with ferntree-gullies recently opened up, where I can make new collections and at the same time see, what the forest-air will do for my pulmonary complaint.

As I just think of it, I would like to ask, whether Mrs Dr Sonder has received the money for her husbands extensive bot. collections from the Agent General. I presume, no prior report was required on the state of the collections after arrival, as the looking through such huge mass of plants would take a long time, and even the repositories are not done yet.
See M to G. Berry, 20 October 1883 (in this edition as 83-10-20a).
